"Dr Beda'e. of Manchester, has underta.
ken ta swim from Liverpool to Runcorn,
distance of % or "a miles, in one tide, on

either corks or bladders. lie is, without
stopping, to partake of Refreshments that
are to be handed him from boat; he is not
70 touch the boat or any thing that may rem.
der him assistance. Bets to large a.
mount against his performing the task are
pending"

The means by which the Commander in
Chief obtained secret intelligence from the
enemy during the War of the Revolution,
and more especall, from New York, the
focus OF Royal dominion, was natter OF
deep speculation to many even OF the Cen
eral Staff. 1t would have probably continu-
ed to BE an affair OF surmise only but for an
accident. Soon after the termination othos-
tilities, Gen. Washington, attended by two
or three favorite officers, repaired to the
store Of -. in New York. for the avowed
purpose of looking at some books. On en-
terng the store, the Genera, asked II the
books " hich he had bespoken were ready
NSill your excellcncy be pleased to walk INTO
this rnom, replied the -, leading the way,
every thing is ready. The door was but In
perfectly closed, and the officers distinctly
heard in succession the chinklng OF two hea-
w purses of gold. as they were placed on
a table. The General soon returned, -
assuring him that he should be most happy
(aS heret2fgrc J at all times, 10 crccufe hi5
orders. The officers became convinced that


it was - the Kings official, who had
been IN The secret scrvice ot the Cammander
Chief of the American Army during near
~ the whole of the war Of the Revelation.

OH what is pleasure, in whose chase,
Life's one brief day is made race


of vanity and lightncss'
star to gaze on, whose bright crown
We wait until the sun goes down,
And find when it has Der us shone,


No warmth in Il! is brightness.
And what is Friendship, that false flower,
Which spreads its leaves at dayiig,.t's houn


And closes them at eve;-
Opening its petals to the light,
Sweet breathing, while the sun shines br sass
But shut to those who midst the night


Ofdoubt and darkness Sr,csc!
And what is flme'-the sn,ilc that Stays
The cup y which sweet poison lays,


At best Aowely wreath;-
That's twind around the victims head,
When midst sweet flowers aroua,l Il spread
And harp's and tnlbrel's sounds, rs led,


,leloliously to death
And what are hopes'--gay butteIil:cf.
Thst on tie breath Of fancy rise.


where c'cr the sunbeam. lures tAam,
Forever, ever, Oh the wing,
Iockiag our faint steps following,
And iftt last caught, Perisling


In the grasp that secures them
And our affections. what arc theys
Oh! blossoms smiling on the spray,


All beauty and all aweetness,--
But which the canke- may lay bare,
Or rude hands from the branches tear.
Or bligh'ing winds lay witherihy there,


Sad types Of mortal aeetness!
And what is life itseif'--a sail,
With sometimes an auspieious gale,


And some bright sunbeams round i's
But Oft midst the tempests cast,
The lowering sky, the howling blast.
And w,elmd beneath the wave at last


Where never p'ummet sounded

The fine gentleman of the good old days.
before the Revolution as he i, described in
the paintings and portraits of the times,
strutted forth in a huge coat of red or white
broad cloth, Of most voluminous dimensions,
whose ample skirts covered his whole per-
son as securely as the outer garments of re-
cent fashions. Broad plates of silyered met
al, or substantial dirks of horn, were ar
ranged i'll rows upon its sides, in the places
of iinical gilded buttons, to pay double
debt, as fastenings aud ornaments. The

will be dissolved immediately. and the new
parliament assemble in the first week of 0c-
tober, when tina opinions entertained by the
ministers of his Majcsty's government npon
the disputes between the various branches
Of the Legislature Of this province will b.
announced.

A few twigs, full of sap, were placed in
a small quantity of water for several days,
until part of the sap became incorporated
with the water. A drop OF this water put
upon the head of a large pin, and by the So
lar microscope, it was found to contain more
than SO. 000 living creatures

The merchants Of the q. States are not aware
OF the impostions that exist in Havana in the
form of a Post Office. All letters, including the
Consignee's, are taken from The vessel, on her
arrival, by the Custom House boat, and dcposit
ed in the Office, when they arc charged accord.
inf to the option of the postmaster from one to
fifteen dollars per letter or package. Merchants
and editors cannot be too cautious in sending
scaled packages of newspapers, &c. A short
/ time since, person paid thirteen dollars for a
small package taken from the office, which was
found to contain u few samples of calico. To a.
void this imposition as s.uch as possible, the bu-
sness ofa letter should be as much concentrated
upon single sheet as can be done with convc-
nience Nothing is allowed vessels for bringing
/ letters to Havana

In the First Presidency. the door OF the
Presidolead gathered but little rust on its
hinges, while often was its latch lifted by
the "broken soldier" Scarce day passed
that some veteran OF the heroic time did not
present himself at Head Quarters. The
most tattered Of these types of the days Of
privation aud trial was "kindly bid to stay,
was offered rcfreshnent, and a glass OF some
,hing to their old Generals health, and then
dismissed with lighter hearts, aud heavier
pouches. So passed the many, bat not so
with one of E.rn's sons. 1t was about the
hour of the Tuesday levee. when German
John, the porter, opened to all hearty rap;
expecting, TO admit at least dlgnitaiy ..
.he land or foreign ambassador, when who
should march into the hall but an ois fellow.
whose weather Count ;nalce, and well worn

knight" Ills introduction was short but to
lhe purpose He had come to Head Quar-
rers, to see his honor's excel.ency, God
bless him. He was an old soldier


In vain the porter assured him that it
would be impossible TO see the President at
that time; great company was monentiy
expected-,he hall was not fitting place
would he go the stewards apartment aud
get something to drink, To all which Pat
replied that he was in no hurry; that he
would wait his honar'o leisure; and taking
chair composed himself comfortably. Aud
now passed Ministers of State, and foreign
Ministers, Senators, Judges; the great and
gay; meanwhile, poor Pat stoutly maintain
ed his post, gazing on the crowd, till the le-
wee having ended, aud the President about
to retire to his library, he was informed
that an obstinate lrishman had taken pos
session OF the hall, aud would be satisfied
with nothing short of an interview with the
President hiuself. The Chief good-natur
edly turned into the hall. so soon as the
veteran saw his old commander, he roared
out: Long life to your honor's excellency, at
the same time hurling his hat to the ground
aud erecting himself with military precision.
''Your honor will not remember me; though
many is the day that have marched under
your orders, and many's the hard knocks
I've had too | belonged to Wayne, brig
adc--llud -datonV, the British called him,
and by the powers, he was always mad
enough for them. | was wounded in the
battle of Germantown. Hu,sa for America
land it does my heart good to see ' our hon
or; and how is the dear lady and all the lit
tie ones" Here the usually grave tenpc"
ament ot " AsiingtOn gave way, as, with
smile he replied, that he was welt, IS was
Mrs. Washington, but they were untortu-
nate in having no children; then pres slug
token into the soldiers hand, he ,cendel
the stair case to his library. The irishm4n
followed with his ewes the retiring General,
ghen looking again and agi IN upon the toke
which he Tad received from HI, A3A9r'3 27rn

The Editors Of the Liverpool Mercury
gives this note, and remark that if they were
IN the habit of gambling, they would bet 20
TO one, that he undertaken of the feat would
fail.


"Dr Beda'e. of Manchester, has underta.
ken ta swim from Liverpool to Runcorn,
distance of % or "a miles, in one tide, on
the 10Th of July, without the assistance of
either corks or bladders. lie is, without
stopping, to partake of Refreshments that
are to be handed him from boat; he is not
70 touch the boat or any thing that may rem.
der him assistance. Bets to large a.
mount against his performing the task are
pending"

At this stage of the examination, adas cur
reporter, monstrous scuffiing was hearn Oh
the stairs leading to the study OF the clergy

forward, and presently in came the WIGS

clerk. who had found out that the skuil III

unhappy gentleman named Muffglns' VINO
had died some forty years since IN conse-
quence of slight accident he had met win
on the gallows. This somewhat pozcd our

upon their honors. that for down right hon
est truth. there was nothing like Phreno'o-

confess, notwithstanding this trilling blum
der; but what of thatf accidents you know
will en,--humanum est errare," as the
poet SAYS.

full articles.headline: BLACKBERRY SYRUP.
full articles.article:
The present being not only a seasonablc
time TO prepare this valuable medicine, but
to recommend its usefulness, particularly a.
mong children afflicted with bowel com.
plants a feeling mother offers the follow
ing recipe


"Fake the fruit before very ripe, extract
the juice, and to each quart add one pound
of white sugar, skim and boil it about half
an hour, when cool enough to bottle, add a
small tea cup full of brandy. From one
to four table spoon fulls may be taken ire.
qucntly, as age and circumstances may re-
quirc."

ed to his Cnief, as to shelter from the fury
Of so many elements. Washington extend-
ed his hand TO one who appeared IN no new
character: for during the whole OF long
life, misfortune seemed to have marked
him for her own" Poor old St. CLAIR hob
bled up to his Chief. sezed the offered hand
m both of his, and gave vent to his feelings
in an audible manner. He was subsequently
tried BY commission of Government and
proved to have been unfortunate.


The means by which the Commander in
Chief obtained secret intelligence from the
enemy during the War of the Revolution,
and more especall, from New York, the
focus OF Royal dominion, was natter OF
deep speculation to many even OF the Cen
eral Staff. 1t would have probably continu-
ed to BE an affair OF surmise only but for an
accident. Soon after the termination othos-
tilities, Gen. Washington, attended by two
or three favorite officers, repaired to the
store Of -. in New York. for the avowed
purpose of looking at some books. On en-
terng the store, the Genera, asked II the
books " hich he had bespoken were ready
NSill your excellcncy be pleased to walk INTO
this rnom, replied the -, leading the way,
every thing is ready. The door was but In
perfectly closed, and the officers distinctly
heard in succession the chinklng OF two hea-
w purses of gold. as they were placed on
a table. The General soon returned, -
assuring him that he should be most happy
(aS heret2fgrc J at all times, 10 crccufe hi5
orders. The officers became convinced that


it was - the Kings official, who had
been IN The secret scrvice ot the Cammander
Chief of the American Army during near
~ the whole of the war Of the Revelation.

full articles.headline: QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS.
full articles.article:
OH what is pleasure, in whose chase,
Life's one brief day is made race


of vanity and lightncss'
star to gaze on, whose bright crown
We wait until the sun goes down,
And find when it has Der us shone,


No warmth in Il! is brightness.
And what is Friendship, that false flower,
Which spreads its leaves at dayiig,.t's houn


And closes them at eve;-
Opening its petals to the light,
Sweet breathing, while the sun shines br sass
But shut to those who midst the night


Ofdoubt and darkness Sr,csc!
And what is flme'-the sn,ilc that Stays
The cup y which sweet poison lays,


At best Aowely wreath;-
That's twind around the victims head,
When midst sweet flowers aroua,l Il spread
And harp's and tnlbrel's sounds, rs led,


,leloliously to death
And what are hopes'--gay butteIil:cf.
Thst on tie breath Of fancy rise.


where c'cr the sunbeam. lures tAam,
Forever, ever, Oh the wing,
Iockiag our faint steps following,
And iftt last caught, Perisling


In the grasp that secures them
And our affections. what arc theys
Oh! blossoms smiling on the spray,


All beauty and all aweetness,--
But which the canke- may lay bare,
Or rude hands from the branches tear.
Or bligh'ing winds lay witherihy there,


Sad types Of mortal aeetness!
And what is life itseif'--a sail,
With sometimes an auspieious gale,


And some bright sunbeams round i's
But Oft midst the tempests cast,
The lowering sky, the howling blast.
And w,elmd beneath the wave at last


Where never p'ummet sounded

.fncient attire and Modern Nanneys.-
The fine gentleman of the good old days.
before the Revolution as he i, described in
the paintings and portraits of the times,
strutted forth in a huge coat of red or white
broad cloth, Of most voluminous dimensions,
whose ample skirts covered his whole per-
son as securely as the outer garments of re-
cent fashions. Broad plates of silyered met
al, or substantial dirks of horn, were ar
ranged i'll rows upon its sides, in the places
of iinical gilded buttons, to pay double
debt, as fastenings aud ornaments. The

The Montreal Herald, of the 9TH instant,
states that the Parliament of Lower Canada
will be dissolved immediately. and the new
parliament assemble in the first week of 0c-
tober, when tina opinions entertained by the
ministers of his Majcsty's government npon
the disputes between the various branches
Of the Legislature Of this province will b.
announced.

A few twigs, full of sap, were placed in
a small quantity of water for several days,
until part of the sap became incorporated
with the water. A drop OF this water put
upon the head of a large pin, and by the So
lar microscope, it was found to contain more
than SO. 000 living creatures

During IN arrnmcnt before the Court of
Errors, at albany on the c8th inst says the
New York Commercial Advertiser, the dis
tinguished Mrs. Royal made her appearance
in the lobby, and disturbed the gravity of
the court. She called out, we are told, one
Of the honorable Senator's, and having fail
ed by gentle accents to persuade him to
patroni2c hrr book, commenced upon him
an attack in her very best Stale of vitupcr-
ative eloqnencc. Ills judEeship was struck
dumb. or, more properly. struck deaf. This
Mrs. ROYAL IS trslv a remarkable woman.
No to any man that comes within the reach
Of her uAra!y member.

The merchants Of the q. States are not aware
OF the impostions that exist in Havana in the
form of a Post Office. All letters, including the
Consignee's, are taken from The vessel, on her
arrival, by the Custom House boat, and dcposit
ed in the Office, when they arc charged accord.
inf to the option of the postmaster from one to
fifteen dollars per letter or package. Merchants
and editors cannot be too cautious in sending
scaled packages of newspapers, &c. A short
/ time since, person paid thirteen dollars for a
small package taken from the office, which was
found to contain u few samples of calico. To a.
void this imposition as s.uch as possible, the bu-
sness ofa letter should be as much concentrated
upon single sheet as can be done with convc-
nience Nothing is allowed vessels for bringing
/ letters to Havana

eyrDtfut evening TO notice orChi0e LUIS wau'
of deccrun, in his brave and well-tried SOL
cler.-.Atter the war, a friend OF the gallant
Generals anxious to reform his evil habit,
asked him, whether it was possible that the
man so much beloved, the admired Wash
ingtou, ever swore? Scott reflected for a mo-
ment, and then exclaimed, "Yes, once. 1t
was at Monmouth, on a lay that would have
made anv man swear. Yes, sir, he swore
Oh that day, till the leaves shook on the trees:
charming, delightful. Never have ENJOY
ed such swearing before, or since. olr, on
chat ever memorable day he swore ike an
Angel from Heaven" The reformer aban
doned the General in despair.


In the First Presidency. the door OF the
Presidolead gathered but little rust on its
hinges, while often was its latch lifted by
the "broken soldier" Scarce day passed
that some veteran OF the heroic time did not
present himself at Head Quarters. The
most tattered Of these types of the days Of
privation aud trial was "kindly bid to stay,
was offered rcfreshnent, and a glass OF some
,hing to their old Generals health, and then
dismissed with lighter hearts, aud heavier
pouches. So passed the many, bat not so
with one of E.rn's sons. 1t was about the
hour of the Tuesday levee. when German
John, the porter, opened to all hearty rap;
expecting, TO admit at least dlgnitaiy ..
.he land or foreign ambassador, when who
should march into the hall but an ois fellow.
whose weather Count ;nalce, and well worn
apparel, shewel him 10 be "no carpet
knight" Ills introduction was short but to
lhe purpose He had come to Head Quar-
rers, to see his honor's excel.ency, God
bless him. He was an old soldier


In vain the porter assured him that it
would be impossible TO see the President at
that time; great company was monentiy
expected-,he hall was not fitting place
would he go the stewards apartment aud
get something to drink, To all which Pat
replied that he was in no hurry; that he
would wait his honar'o leisure; and taking
chair composed himself comfortably. Aud
now passed Ministers of State, and foreign
Ministers, Senators, Judges; the great and
gay; meanwhile, poor Pat stoutly maintain
ed his post, gazing on the crowd, till the le-
wee having ended, aud the President about
to retire to his library, he was informed
that an obstinate lrishman had taken pos
session OF the hall, aud would be satisfied
with nothing short of an interview with the
President hiuself. The Chief good-natur
edly turned into the hall. so soon as the
veteran saw his old commander, he roared
out: Long life to your honor's excellency, at
the same time hurling his hat to the ground
aud erecting himself with military precision.
''Your honor will not remember me; though
many is the day that have marched under
your orders, and many's the hard knocks
I've had too | belonged to Wayne, brig
adc--llud -datonV, the British called him,
and by the powers, he was always mad
enough for them. | was wounded in the
battle of Germantown. Hu,sa for America
land it does my heart good to see ' our hon
or; and how is the dear lady and all the lit
tie ones" Here the usually grave tenpc"
ament ot " AsiingtOn gave way, as, with
smile he replied, that he was welt, IS was
Mrs. Washington, but they were untortu-
nate in having no children; then pres slug
token into the soldiers hand, he ,cendel
the stair case to his library. The irishm4n
followed with his ewes the retiring General,
ghen looking again and agi IN upon the toke
which he Tad received from HI, A3A9r'3 27rn
hand, loucned it, recovered his har whici
he placed Sth military exactnees little
on one side theu took up his line Of march,
and as he passed the port,r, called out taere
now YOU H"ssian fellow n see that MS
honor's excellence has nat t1rg9ttea an oM
soldier.


These anecdotes, though simple in them
selves, possess no common character. Ihcl
are Tales ofthe Days IF Washington, and
Tales of the Heart, We proceed to some-
thing OF a 9raver sort


The President was dining, when an officer
arrived from the Western Army with dcs-
patches, his oriers requiring that he should
deliver then only to the Commander III
Chief. The President retired hut soon re-
appeared. bearing in his hand an opened let
ter Nc change was perceptiple in his couH.
tenance, as addressing the company he OBJ
served that the army of st Clair had been
surprised by the Indians, and was cut t,
pieces. The coinpany soon after retired
The President repaired to his private par
lor attended byMr. Lear, his principal Sec.
retary, and a scene en;ned of which our pen
can give but feeble d, scription


The Chief paced the room in hurried
strides, 1n his agony, he struck his clench.
ed hands with fearful force against his fore
head. and in paroxy SIN of anguish exclaim


ed: That brave army, so ofiicered-Butler
Ferguson, Kirkwood-such officers are no,
20 be replaced in adly--that brave army Gu
70 pieces, Oh, God!' Then turning to tn,
Secretary, who stood amazed at a spectacl,
so unique, as Washington in all his terrors
he continued "It was here. sir, in this ye
~ room, that conversed with st. Clair, or
the very eve of his departure for the West

with the orders of General Knox, and tn


War Department; they are sufficiently com
prehensive and judicious; but a old SO!


der, as one whose early life was particular

The people of color in the .icin;ty Of
Coope rstown, Ostego county, y. Y.as,em-
bled IN that viilage on the 18th inst. to cele-
brate the day ot their emancipation from
slavery in that state. About twelve O'Clock
they proceeded to the Presbyterian Meeting
House, when Mr.. Hayden Waters, man
OF color and an industrious tara,er, delivered
an oration TO his lorethern OH the occasion -
Good order ard propriety marked all their
proceedings
